FtaRooDetails.FtaFullName: THE MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING BETWEEN THE GOVERNMENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF INDONESIA AND THE GOVERNMENT OF THE STATE OF PALESTINE ON TRADE FACILITATION FOR CERTAIN PRODUCTS ORIGINATING FROM PALESTINIAN TERRITORIES
FtaRooDetails.AdminProc:
Now you will need to complete a certificate of origin (CoO) in order to demonstrate that your product indeed qualifies under the rules of origin.
It will have to be presented at the customs of the destination country during the clearance procedure, when the customs officer asks whether your product qualifies under Indonesia-Palestine
FtaRooDetails.AdminProcCooAuth: The certification type under Indonesia-Palestine is by authorized body. This means that certificate of origin is issued by an agency empowered for this purpose.
FtaRooDetails.AdminProcCooNoAuth: The certification type under Indonesia-Palestine is self-certification. This means that certificate of origin can be issued by the exporter himself.
FtaRooDetails.AdminProcDownload: 1. Download and complete the certificate of origin (CoO) for Indonesia-Palestine agreement.
FtaRooDetails.RooSelfAssessmentDesc:
In order to qualify for preferential treatment, your product will need to satisfy the rules of origin under the agreement.
Complete this short self-assessment to find out whether your product may qualify in relation to this tariff line.
FtaRooDetails.AddlMrktInfoDesc:
In the following are deep links to additional information available in other ITC tools.
If you have any questions about that please contact us at marketanalysis@intracen.org.

RooData.RooText: (a) For the purposes of Rule 2(b), a product shall be deemed to be originating of Palestine if: (i) the total value of the materials, parts or products originating from outside of Palestine does not exceed 65% of the Ex-Works Price value of the product provided that the final process of the manufacture is performed within Palestine; or (ii) all non-originating materials of Palestine used in the production of the good have undergone in Palestine a Change in Tarif Classification (hereinafer referred to as "CTC") at the 4.-digit level (i.e. a Change in Tariff Heading) of Harmonized System.

RooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision which allows to consider goods obtained in as well as processing taking place in one FTA member country as originating in another.

A provision that allows a small amount of non-originating materials to be used in the production of the good without affecting its originating status. The provision acts as the relaxation of the rules of origin.
RooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Rule 7: De Minimis
(a) A product that does not undergo a change in tarif classification shall be
considered as originating if the value of all non-originating materials of
Palestine used in its production that do not undergo the required change
in tarif classification does not exceed ten per cent (10%) of the Ex-Works
Price value of the product and the product meets all other applicable
criteria set forth in this Annex for qualifying as an originating product.
(b) The value of non-originating materials of Palestine referred to in
paragraph (a) of this Rule shall, however, be included in the value of
non-originating materials of Palestine for any applicable value added
requirement for the product.

RooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision stipulating that once a part or intermediate material obtains originating status under an FTA, it is considered to be 100% originating when used for further processing even if inputs used for the production of this part or intermediate material were not originating.

A provision that relates to reclaims or refunds of customs duties previously paid on inputs. In the context of FTAs, duty drawback provision, usually relates to the ability to claim back duties paid on non-originating materials used to produce the final good which is exported under preferential tariffs.

A provision that allows a good to be temporarily removed from the FTA territory and processed in the third party country without affecting origin determination of the final product. No account is taken of the fact that the good has left the territory of an FTA during the production process.
A provision that clarifies the origin determination process of accessories, spare parts or tools delivered with the good.
RooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Rule 10: Accessories, Spare Parts and Tools
The origin of accessories, spare parts, tools and instructional or other
information materials presented with the goods therewith shall not be
considered in determining the origin of the products, provided that such
accessories, spare parts, tools and information materials are classified and
collected import duties with the products by Indonesia.

RooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision listing products considered obtained entirely in the territory of one (or more, depending on the agreement) FTA party without the addition of any non-originating materials.
RooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Rule 3: Wholly Obtained/Produced Products
Within the meaning of Rule 2 (a), the following shall be considered as wholly
obtained/produced in Palestine:
(a) Plant and plant products harvested, picked or gathered there;
(b) Live animals born and raised there;
(c) Products obtained from live animals referred to in paragraph (b) above;
(d) Products obtained from hunting, trapping, fishing, aquaculture, gathering
or capturing conducted there;
(e) Minerals and other naturally occurring substances, not included in
paragraphs (a) to (d), extracted or taken from its soil, waters, seabed or
beneath their seabed;
(f) Products taken from the waters, seabed or beneath the seabed outside
the territorial waters of Palestine, provided that Palestine has the rights to
exploit such waters, seabed and beneath the seabed in accordance with international law;
Products of sea fishing and other marine products taken from the high
seas by vessels registered with Palestine or entitled to fly the flag of Palestine;
Products processed and/or made on board factory ships registered with
Palestine or entitled to fly the flag of Palestine, exclusively from products
referred to in paragraph (g) above;
Articles collected there which can no longer perform their original
purpose nor are capable of being restored or repaired and are fit only for
disposal or recovery of parts of raw materials, or for recycling purposes;
Goods obtained/produced in Palestine solely from products referred to in
paragraphs (a) to (i) above.

RooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision that lists operations which do not confer origin. They are considered below the threshold of sufficient production / processing.
RooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Rule 6: Minimal Operations and Processes
The operations or processes, listed below, undertaken by Palestine shall be
considered to be minimal and shall not be taken into account in determining
whether or not a good is originating:
(a) preservation of products in good condition for the purposes of transport or storage;
(b) changes of packaging, or breaking-up and assembly of packages;
(c) simple cleaning, including removal of oxide, oil, paint or other coverings;
(d) simple painting and polishing operations;
(e) simple testing or calibration;
(f) husking, partial or total bleaching, polishing and glazing of cereals arid rice;
(g) sharpening, simple grinding, slicing or simple cutting;
(h) simple placing in bottles, cans, flasks, bags, cases, boxes, fixing on
cards or boards and all other simple packaging operations;
(i) afixing or printing marks, labels, logos and other like distinguishing signs
on products or their packaging;
0) simple mixing of products, whether or not of different kinds;
(k) simple assembly of parts of products to constitute a complete product.

RooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision that provides how to calculate regional value content in the shipped good.
RooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Rule 4: Not Wholly Obtained/ Produced
(b) for the purpose of Rule 4 (a) (i) above, the formula for the non-originating
materials of Palestine materials is calculated as follows:
(Value of non-originating materials of Palestine / Ex-Works Price) X 100 % <= 65%
(c) The value of the non-originating materials of Palestine shall be:
(i) the CIF value at the time of importation of the materials; or
(ii) the earliest ascertained price paid for the materials of undetermined
origin in Palestine where the working or processing takes place.

RooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision which specifies that the origin of certain materials (referred to as indirect or neutral) used in the production process should not be taken into account when determining the origin of the final good.
RooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Rule 11: Indirect Materials
In order to determine whether a product originates in Palestine, any indirect
material used to obtain such product shall be treated as originating whether
such material originates in non-Parties or not, and its value shall be the cost
registered in the accounting records of the producer of the export products,
such as the following:
(a) fuel, energy, catalysts and solvents;
(b) equipment, devices and supplies used for testing or inspection of the products;
(c) gloves, glasses, footwear, clothing, safety equipment and supplies;
(d) tools, dies and moulds;
(e) spare parts and materials used in the maintenance of equipment and buildings;
(0 lubricants, greases, compounding materials and other materials used in
production or used to operate equipment and buildings; and
(g) any other products which are not incorporated into the product but whose
use in the production of the product can reasonably be demonstrated to
be a part of that production;

RooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision requiring goods that are claiming preferential treatment under an FTA to be shipped directly from the FTA country of origin to the FTA country of destination.
RooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Rule 8: Direct Consignment
The following shall be considered as consigned directly from Palestine to Indonesia:
(a) The products are transported without passing through the territory of any
intermediate non-Parties; or
(b) The products whose transport involves transit through one or more
intermediate non-Parties with or without transhipment or temporary
storage in such countries, provided that:
(i) the transit entry is justified for geographical reason or by
consideration related exclusively to transport requirements;
(ii) the products have not entered into trade or consumption there; and
(iii) the products have not undergone any operation there other than
unloading and reloading or any operation required to keep them in good condition.
CONSIGNMENT DOCUMENT
Article 19:
For the purpose of implementing Rule 8 (Direct Consignment) of Annex II
(Rules of Origin) where transportation is efected through the territory of any
non-Parties, the following shall be provided to the Customs Authority of Indonesia:
a) a through Bill of Lading issued in Palestine; or
b) a certificate or any other information given by the customs authority of such
non-Parties or other relevant entities, which evidences that the good has not
undergone operations other than unloading, reloading and any other
operation to preserve it in good condition in those non-Parties.

RooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision stating that for the purpose of determining the origin of goods, all working and processing needs to be carried out within the territory of parties to the agreement without interruption.
A provision that clarifies whether packaging should be accounted for when determining the origin of the product.
RooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Rule 9: Treatment of Packages and Packing Materials
(a) If the product is subject to the value-added criterion, the value of the
packages and packing materials for retail sale shall be taken into account
in its origin assessment, in case the packing is considered as forming a
whole with products.
(b) Where paragraph (a) above is not applied, the packages and packing
materials shall not be taken into account in determining the origin of the products.
(c) The containers and packing materials exclusively used for the transport
of a product shall not be taken into account for determining the origin of any product.

RooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision determining how non-originating and originating fungible materials should be tracked (accounted for) when both types are stored together and/or used to produce originating and non-originating goods. It allows both types of goods to be tracked not through physical identification and separation but based on an accounting or inventory management system.
A provision that clarifies circumstances under which sets can be considered originating. In particular, it refers to situations where not all of the items in the set are originating.
A provision which allows an originating good to be purchased in a third party (non-FTA) country during an exhibition and imported into an FTA country under preferential treatment.

CooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision that details the type of origin documentation that needs to be provided to claim preferential tariffs under an FTA.
CooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Rule 12: Certificate of Origin
A claim that products shall be accepted as eligible for tarifs elimination shall be
supported by a Certificate of Origin as set out in "Form P" of Attachment A
issued by a Competent Governmental Authority and notified to Indonesia in
accordance with the Operational Certification Procedures.
Attachment A
OPERATIONAL CERTIFICATION PROCEDURES FOR THE RULES OF
ORIGIN FOR TARIFFS ELIMINATION OF INDONESIA FOR PALESTINE
For the purpose of implementing the Rules of Origin under the Implementing
Arrangement of the Memorandum of Understanding between the Government
of the Republic of Indonesia and the Government of the State of Palestine on
Trade Facilitation for Certain Products Originating from Palestinian Territories,
the following operational procedures on the issuance and verification of the
Certificate of Origin (Form P) and the other related administrative matters shall apply:
ISSUING AUTHORITY
Article 1:
The Certificate of Origin shall be issued by the Competent Governmental Authority.
Article 2:
(a) Palestine shall inform Indonesia the names and addresses of its
Competent Governmental Authority issuing the Certificate of Origin and
shall provide specimen signatures and specimen of oficial seals used by
its said Competent Governmental Authority, in hard copy and soft copy format.
(b) Any change in names, addresses, or oficial seals shall be promptly
informed in the same manner as stated above.
Article 3:
For the purpose of verifying the conditions for tarifs elimination treatment, the
Competent Governmental Authority designated to issue the Certificate of Origin
shall have the right to call for any supporting documentary evidence or to carry
out any check considered appropriate. If such right cannot be obtained through
the existing national laws and regulations, it shall be inserted as a clause in the
application form referred to in the following Article 4 and 5.
PRE-EXPORTATION VERIFICATION
Article 4:
The exporter and/or the manufacturer of the products qualified for tarifs
elimination treatment shall apply in writing to the Competent Governmental
Authority requesting for the pre-exportation verification of the origin of the
products. The result of the verification, subject to review periodically or
whenever appropriate, shall be accepted as the supporting evidence in verifying
the origin of the said products to be exported thereafter. The pre-verification
may not apply to the products of which, by their nature, origin can be easily verified.
APPLICATION OF CERTIFICATE OF ORIGIN
Article 5:
At the time of carrying out the formalities for exporting the products under tarifs
elimination treatment, the exporter or his authorized representative shall submit
a written application for the Certificate of Origin together with appropriate
supporting documents proving that the products to be exported qualify fc; the
issuance of a Certificate of Origin.
Article 6:
The Competent Governmental Authority designated to issue the Certificate of
Origin shall, to the best of their competence and ability, carry out proper
examination upon each application for the Certificate of Origin to ensure that:
(a) The app!ication and the Certificate of Origin are duly completed' and
signed by the authorized signatory;
(b) The origin of the product is in conformity with the Annex II (Rules of Origin);
(c) The other statements of the Certificate of Origin correspond to supporting
documentary evidence submitted;
(d) HS Code, Value, Description and quantity conform to the products to be exported;
(e) Multiple items declared on the same Certificate of Origin (Form P) shall
be allowed provided that each item qualifies separately in its own right..
CERTIFICATE OF ORIGIN
Article 7:
(a) The Certificate of Origin must be on ISO A4 size paper in conformity to
the specimen as shown in Form P. It shall be made in English.
(b) The Certificate of Origin shall comprise one original and two copies.
(c) Each Certificate of Origin shall bear a reference number separately given
by each place or ofice of issuance.
(d) The original shall be forwarded, by the exporter to the importer for
submission to the Customs Authority of Indonesia at the port of place of
importation. Duplicate copy shall be retained by the issuing authority in
the exporting country, and the triplicate copy shall be retained by the exporter.
(e) The validity of the Certificate of Origin shall be 12 months from the date of its issuance.
Article 8:
To implement the 'provisions of Rule 2 of the Annex II (Rules of Origin), the
Certificate of Origin issued by Palestine shall specify the relevant origin
conferring criteria in the relevant column of the Form P.
TREATMENT OF ERRONEOUS
Article 9:
Neither erasures nor superimposition shall be allowed on the Certificate of
Origin. Any alterations shall be made by striking out the erroneous materials
and making any additions required. Such alterations shall be approved by an
authorized signatory of the applicant and certified by the appropriate Competent
Governmental Authority. Unused spaces shall be crossed out to prevent any subsequent adciition.
ISSUANCE OF CERTIFICATE OF ORIGIN
Article 10:
a) The Certificate of Origin shall be issued by the Competent Governmental
Authority before or at the time of exportation or within 3 working days
thereafer whenever the products to be exported can be considered
originating Palestine within the meaning of the Rules of Origin.
b) In exceptional cases where a Certificate of Origin has not been issued
before or at the time of exportation or soon thereafer due to involuntary
errors or omissions or other valid causes, the Certificate of Origin may be
issued retroactively but no longer than 12 months from the date of shipment,
bearing the words "ISSUED RETROSPECTIVELY" in Box 11 of Form P.
Article 11:
In the event of thef, loss or destruction of a Certificate of Origin, the exporter
may apply in writing to the Competent Governmental Authority, which issued it,
for the certified true copy of the original and the triplicate to be made on the
basis of the export documents in their possession bearing the endorsement of
the words "CERTIFIED TRUE COPY".in Box 13. This copy shall bear the date
of the original Certificate of Origin. The certified true copy of a Certificate of
Origin shall be issued within the validity period of the original certificate.

CooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision which lists exemptions from the requirement to provide a proof of origin. Under certain circumstances originating goods can be imported into an FTA country without a proof of origin and still be treated as originating.
CooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Article 14:
In the case of consignments of products originating in Palestine and not
exceeding US$200.00 Ex-Works Price, the production of a Certificate of Origin
shall be waived and the use of simplified declaration by the exporter that the
products in questioned have originated in Palestine will be accepted.

CooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: Approved exporter provision refers to exporters who fulfil certain conditions, export frequently under and FTA and are registered with the local customs authorities (have obtained an approved exporter authorisation).

A provision that lists national authorities responsible for overseeing origin-related provisions and for issuing the certificate of origin. This is often the government or a government department which can then delegate the procedure of issuing certificates to other domestic organisations.
A provision that specifies the length of time an origin certificate or an origin declaration (see proof of origin) is valid for from the moment it has been issued.
CooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Article 7:
(e) The validity of the Certificate of Origin shall be 12 months from the date of its issuance.

CooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision that specifies who (exporter, producer who issued a supplier declaration, importer, issuing or accepting customs authority) and for what period of time needs to retain the proof of origin.
CooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Article 16:
a) For the purposes of the verification process pursuant to Article 17 and 18,
the producer and/or exporter applying for the issuance of a Certificate of
Origin shall, subject to the domestic laws and regulations of Palestine, keep
its supporting records for application for not less than three (3) years from
the date of issuance of the Certificate of Origin.
b) The importer shall keep records relevant to the importation in accordance
with the domestic laws and regulations of Indonesia.
c) The application for Certificates of Origin and all documents related to such
application shall be retained by the Competent Governmental Authority for
not less than three (3) years from the date of issuance.
d) Information relating to the validity of a Certificate of Origin shall be furnished
upon request of the importing Party, by an oficial authorised to sign a
Certificate of Origin and certified by the appropriate government authorities.
e) Any information communicated between the Parties concerned shall be
treated as confidential and shall be used for the validation of Certificates of
Origin purpose only.

CooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision that allows to recover customs duties paid for originating goods at the time of import.
CooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Article 10:
b) In exceptional cases where a Certificate of Origin has not been issued
before or at the time of exportation or soon thereafer due to involuntary
errors or omissions or other valid causes, the Certificate of Origin may be
issued retroactively but no longer than 12 months from the date of shipment,
bearing the words "ISSUED RETROSPECTIVELY" in Box 11 of Form P.

CooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision that lists documentation relating to imports of preferential goods that needs to be submitted at the point of import in addition to the proof of origin.

A provision that refers to a situation where the commercial invoice is issued by a party other than the party which manufactured the goods or a party from which premises the good has been shipped. This third party can be an entity related to the exporter or an unrelated party. The third party can be located in FTA territory or outside.

A provision which sets out a process for origin verification that an FTA party should follow if the customs authorities of that country have a reasonable doubt regarding the preferential origin of imported goods.
CooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Article 11:
PRESENTATION OF CERTIFICATE OF ORIGIN
Article 12:
The Original Certificate of Origin shall be submitted by the importer or its
authorized representative to the Customs Authority of Indonesia at the time of
import for the products concerned.
Article 13:
The following time limit for the presentation of the Certificate of Origin shall be observed:
a) Certificate of Origin shall be submitted to the Customs Authority of Indonesia
within its validity period; or
b) Where the Certificate of Origin is submitted to the Customs Authority of
Indonesia after the expiration of the time limit for its submission, such
Certificate is still to be accepted when failure to observe the time limit results
from force majeure or other valid causes beyond the control of the exporter.
EXEMPTION FROM CERTIFICATE OF ORIGIN
Article 17:
a) The Customs Authority of Indonesia may request a retroactive check at
random and/or when it has reasonable doubt as to the authenticity of the
document or as to the accuracy of the information regarding the true origin
of the products in question or of certain parts thereof.
b) The request shall be accompanied with the copy of Certificate of Origin
concerned and shall specify the reasons and any additional information
suggesting that the particulars given on the said Certificate of Origin may be
inaccurate, unless the retroactive check is requested on a random basis.
c) The Customs Authority of Indonesia may suspend the provisions on tariffs
elimination treatment while awaiting the result of verification. However, it
may release the products to the importer subject to any administrative
measures deemed necessary, provided that they are not held to be subject
to import prohibition or restriction and there is no suspicion of fraud.
d) The Competent Governmental Authority receiving a request for retroactive
check shall respond to the request promptly and reply not later than sixty
(60) calendar days after the receipt of the request.
Article 18:
(a) If the Customs Authority of Indonesia is not satisfied with the outcome of the
retroactive check, it may, under exceptional cases, request for verification
visits to Palestine.
(i) Prior to the conduct of a verification visit pursuant to the provisions
herein, the Customs Authority of Indonesia shall notify the Competent
Governmental Authority with an aim to mutually agree on the conditions
and means of the verification visit.
(ii) The verification visit shall be conducted not later than sixty (60)
calendar days after receipt of the notification pursuant to sub-paragraph
(a) (i).
(b) The verification process, including the retroactive check and verification
visit, shall be carried out and its results communicated to the Customs
Authority of Indonesia and/or the Competent Governmental Authority within
a maximum of one hundred and eighty (180) calendar days. While awaiting
the results of the verification visit, Article 17 (c) on the suspension of tarifs
elimination treatment shall be applied.
(c) The tarifs elimination treatment may be denied when Palestine fails to
respond to the request to the satisfaction of the Customs Authority of
Indonesia in the course of a retroactive check or verification process, as the
case may be, within the time frame for verification under Article 17, Article
18 paragraphs (a) and (b).

CooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision that specifies the legal consequences of submitting an origin documentation based on incorrect or falsified information. These can relate to criminal, civil and administrative penalties.
CooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Article 20:
a) When it is suspected that fraudulent acts in connection with the Certificate of
Origin have been committed, the Competent Governmental Authority
concerned shall co-operate in the action to be taken in the territory of the
respective Party against the persons involved.
b) Each Party shall be responsible for providing legal sanctions for fraudulent
acts related to the Certificate of Origin.

CooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision that allows an exporter or an importer to obtain an official and legally binding opinion on the classification, origin or customs value of their products from the local customs authorities prior to exporting/importing of the goods.
A provision that clarifies that when the origin of the goods is not in question, preferential origin claims should not be rejected as a result of small administrative errors and discrepancies.
CooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Article 15:
a) The discovery of minor discrepancies between the statements made in the
Certificate of Origin and those made in the documents submitted to the
Customs Authority of Indonesia for the purpose of carrying out the formalities
for importing the products, such as typing errors, shall not ipso-facto
invalidate the Certificate of Origin, if it does in fact correspond to the products submitted.
b) For multiple items declared under the same Certificate of Origin, a problem
encountered with one of the items listed shall not afect or delay the granting
of tarifs elimination treatment and customs clearance of the remaining items
listed in that Certificate of Origin. Article 17 (c) may be applied to the problematic items.

CooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision which sets up an appeal process in respect of origin determination and advanced rulings.
CooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Article 21:
In the case of a dispute concerning origin determination, classification of
products or other matters, the Competent Governmental Authority concerned in
both the importing and the exporting party shall consult each other with a view
to resolve the dispute, and the result shall be reported to the other Party for information.

(c) The value of the non-originating materials of Palestine shall be:
Rule 9: Treatment of Packages and Packing Materials
origin in Palestine where the working or processing takes place.
(a) If the product is subject to the value-added criterion, the value of the
packages and packing materials for retail sale shall be taken into account
in its origin assessment, in case the packing is considered as forming a
whole with products.
(b) Where paragraph (a) above is not applied, the packages and packing
The origin of accessories, spare parts, tools and instructional or other
materials shall not be taken into account in determining the origin of the products.
(c) The containers and packing materials exclusively used for the transport
of a product shall not be taken into account for determining the origin of any product.

information materials presented with the goods therewith shall not be
considered in determining the origin of the products, provided that such
accessories, spare parts, tools and information materials are classified and
collected import duties with the products by Indonesia.

ANNEX II

Rule 1: Definitions
For the purpose of this Annex:
(a) "materials" shall include raw materials, ingredients, parts, components,
sub-components, sub-assembly and/or goods that were physically
incorporated into another good or were subject to a process in the
production of another good;
(b) "originating products" means products that qualify as originating in
accordance with the provisions of Rule 2;
(c) "production" means methods of obtaining goods including growing,
mining, harvesting, raising, breeding, extracting, gathering, collecting,
capturing, fishing, trapping, hunting, manufacturing, producing,
processing or assembling a good;
(d) "products" means products which are wholly obtained/produced or being
manufactured, even if it is intended for later use in another manufacturing operation;
(e) "Competent Governmental Authority" means Ministry of National
Economy of the State of Palestine;
(f) "CIF" means the value of the good imported, and includes the cost of
freight and insurance up to the port or place of entry into the country of importation;
(g) "Ex-Works Price" means the price paid or payable for the good to the
manufacturer in Palestine in whose undertaking the last working or
processing is carried out, provided that the price includes the value of all
the materials used, excluding any internal taxes which are, or may be
repaid when the good obtained is exported;
"Harmonized System" means the Harmonized Commodity Description
and Coding System agreed to under the WCO;
"Product Specific Rules" are rules that specify that the materials have
undergone a change in tarif classification or a specific manufacturing or
processing operation, or satisfy an ad-valorem criterion or a combination
of any of these criteria or any other criteria agreed by the Parties.

Rule 2: Origin Criteria
For the purposes of this Implementing Arrangement, products imported by
Indonesia from Palestine shall be deemed to be originating of Palestine and
eligible for tarifs elimination if they conform to the origin requirements under
any one of the following:
(a) products which are wholly obtained/produced as set out and defined in Rule 3; or
(b) products not wholly obtained/produced provided that the said products
are eligible under Rule 4 or Rule 5.

Rule 3: Wholly Obtained/Produced Products

Rule 5: Product Specific Criteria
Products which satisfy the Product Specific Rules provided for in Attachment B
shall be considered as originating and eligible for tarifs elimination treatment.

ANNEX II

Attachment A
OPERATIONAL CERTIFICATION PROCEDURES FOR THE RULES OF
The following time limit for the presentation of the Certificate of Origin shall be observed:
ORIGIN FOR TARIFFS ELIMINATION OF INDONESIA FOR PALESTINE
For the purpose of implementing the Rules of Origin under the Implementing
Arrangement of the Memorandum of Understanding between the Government
of the Republic of Indonesia and the Government of the State of Palestine on
Trade Facilitation for Certain Products Originating from Palestinian Territories,
the following operational procedures on the issuance and verification of the
Certificate of Origin (Form P) and the other related administrative matters shall apply:
issuance of a Certificate of Origin.
ISSUING AUTHORITY
Article 1:
The Certificate of Origin shall be issued by the Competent Governmental Authority.
Article 2:
(a) Palestine shall inform Indonesia the names and addresses of its
Competent Governmental Authority issuing the Certificate of Origin and
examination upon each application for the Certificate of Origin to ensure that:
shall provide specimen signatures and specimen of oficial seals used by
Article 18:
its said Competent Governmental Authority, in hard copy and soft copy format.
(b) Any change in names, addresses, or oficial seals shall be promptly
informed in the same manner as stated above.
Article 3:
For the purpose of verifying the conditions for tarifs elimination treatment, the
Competent Governmental Authority designated to issue the Certificate of Origin
shall have the right to call for any supporting documentary evidence or to carry
ARTICLE 5:
out any check considered appropriate. If such right cannot be obtained through
the existing national laws and regulations, it shall be inserted as a clause in the
Verification of Origin
application form referred to in the following Article 4 and 5.
Article 19:
PRE-EXPORTATION VERIFICATION
Article 4:
The exporter and/or the manufacturer of the products qualified for tarifs
elimination treatment shall apply in writing to the Competent Governmental
ARTICLE 6:
Authority requesting for the pre-exportation verification of the origin of the
products. The result of the verification, subject to review periodically or
(c) the other statements of the Certificate of Origin correspond to supporting
whenever appropriate, shall be accepted as the supporting evidence in verifying
the origin of the said products to be exported thereafter. The pre-verification
may not apply to the products of which, by their nature, origin can be easily verified.
APPLICATION OF CERTIFICATE OF ORIGIN
concerned and shall specify the reasons and any additional information
At the time of carrying out the formalities for exporting the products under tarifs
elimination treatment, the exporter or his authorized representative shall submit
a written application for the Certificate of Origin together with appropriate
supporting documents proving that the products to be exported qualify fc; the
concerned shall co-operate in the action to be taken in the territory of the
respective Party against the persons involved.
The Competent Governmental Authority designated to issue the Certificate of
Origin shall, to the best of their competence and ability, carry out proper
(a) The app!ication and the Certificate of Origin are duly completed' and
Neither erasures nor superimposition shall be allowed on the certificate of
signed by the authorized signatory;
(b) The origin of the product is in conformity with the Annex II (Rules of Origin);
documentary evidence submitted;
(d) HS Code, Value, Description and quantity conform to the products to be exported;
RECORD KEEPING REQUIREMENT
(e) Multiple items declared on the same Certificate of Origin (Form P) shall
be allowed provided that each item qualifies separately in its own right..
Article 10:
CERTIFICATE OF ORIGIN
Presentation of Certificate of Origin
Article 7:
(a) The Certificate of Origin must be on ISO A4 size paper in conformity to
the specimen as shown in Form P. It shall be made in English.
(b) The Certificate of Origin shall comprise one original and two copies.
(c) Each Certificate of Origin shall bear a reference number separately given
by each place or ofice of issuance.
(d) The original shall be forwarded, by the exporter to the importer for
submission to the Customs Authority of Indonesia at the port of place of
ARTICLE 8:
importation. Duplicate copy shall be retained by the issuing authority in
the exporting country, and the triplicate copy shall be retained by the exporter.
(e) The validity of the Certificate of Origin shall be 12 months from the date of its issuance.
To implement the 'provisions of Rule 2 of the Annex II (Rules of Origin), the
Certificate of Origin issued by Palestine shall specify the relevant origin
conferring criteria in the relevant column of the Form P.
TREATMENT OF ERRONEOUS
Article 9:
Article 15:
Origin. Any alterations shall be made by striking out the erroneous materials
and making any additions required. Such alterations shall be approved by an
authorized signatory of the applicant and certified by the appropriate Competent
Governmental Authority. Unused spaces shall be crossed out to prevent any subsequent adciition.
Article 17:
ISSUANCE OF CERTIFICATE OF ORIGIN
a) The Certificate of Origin shall be issued by the Competent Governmental
Authority before or at the time of exportation or within 3 working days
thereafer whenever the products to be exported can be considered
originating Palestine within the meaning of the Rules of Origin.
b) In exceptional cases where a Certificate of Origin has not been issued
before or at the time of exportation or soon thereafer due to involuntary
errors or omissions or other valid causes, the Certificate of Origin may be
issued retroactively but no longer than 12 months from the date of shipment,
bearing the words "ISSUED RETROSPECTIVELY" in Box 11 of Form P.
Article 11:
In the event of thef, loss or destruction of a Certificate of Origin, the exporter
may apply in writing to the Competent Governmental Authority, which issued it,
for the certified true copy of the original and the triplicate to be made on the
basis of the export documents in their possession bearing the endorsement of
Certificate is still to be accepted when failure to observe the time limit results
the words "CERTIFIED TRUE COPY".in Box 13. This copy shall bear the date
of the original Certificate of Origin. The certified true copy of a Certificate of
Origin shall be issued within the validity period of the original certificate.
ARTICLE 12:
The Original Certificate of Origin shall be submitted by the importer or its
ARTICLE 13:
authorized representative to the Customs Authority of Indonesia at the time of
import for the products concerned.
a) Certificate of Origin shall be submitted to the Customs Authority of Indonesia
within its validity period; or
b) Where the Certificate of Origin is submitted to the Customs Authority of
Indonesia after the expiration of the time limit for its submission, such
from force majeure or other valid causes beyond the control of the exporter.
EXEMPTION FROM CERTIFICATE OF ORIGIN
Article 14:
In the case of consignments of products originating in Palestine and not
exceeding US$200.00 Ex-Works Price, the production of a Certificate of Origin
shall be waived and the use of simplified declaration by the exporter that the
products in questioned have originated in Palestine will be accepted.
TREATMENT OF MINOR DISCREPANCIES
a) The discovery of minor discrepancies between the statements made in the
Certificate of Origin and those made in the documents submitted to the
Customs Authority of Indonesia for the purpose of carrying out the formalities
for importing the products, such as typing errors, shall not ipso-facto
invalidate the Certificate of Origin, if it does in fact correspond to the products submitted.
b) For multiple items declared under the same Certificate of Origin, a problem
encountered with one of the items listed shall not afect or delay the granting
of tarifs elimination treatment and customs clearance of the remaining items
listed in that Certificate of Origin. Article 17 (c) may be applied to the problematic items.
a) For the purposes of the verification process pursuant to Article 17 and 18,
the producer and/or exporter applying for the issuance of a Certificate of
Origin shall, subject to the domestic laws and regulations of Palestine, keep
its supporting records for application for not less than three (3) years from
the date of issuance of the Certificate of Origin.
b) The importer shall keep records relevant to the importation in accordance
with the domestic laws and regulations of Indonesia.
c) The application for Certificates of Origin and all documents related to such
application shall be retained by the Competent Governmental Authority for
ARTICLE 16:
not less than three (3) years from the date of issuance.
d) Information relating to the validity of a Certificate of Origin shall be furnished
upon request of the importing Party, by an oficial authorised to sign a
Certificate of Origin and certified by the appropriate government authorities.
e) Any information communicated between the Parties concerned shall be
treated as confidential and shall be used for the validation of Certificates of
Origin purpose only.
a) The Customs Authority of Indonesia may request a retroactive check at
random and/or when it has reasonable doubt as to the authenticity of the
document or as to the accuracy of the information regarding the true origin
of the products in question or of certain parts thereof.
b) The request shall be accompanied with the copy of Certificate of Origin
suggesting that the particulars given on the said Certificate of Origin may be
inaccurate, unless the retroactive check is requested on a random basis.
c) The Customs Authority of Indonesia may suspend the provisions on tariffs
elimination treatment while awaiting the result of verification. However, it
may release the products to the importer subject to any administrative
measures deemed necessary, provided that they are not held to be subject
to import prohibition or restriction and there is no suspicion of fraud.
d) The Competent Governmental Authority receiving a request for retroactive
check shall respond to the request promptly and reply not later than sixty
(60) calendar days after the receipt of the request.
(a) If the Customs Authority of Indonesia is not satisfied with the outcome of the
retroactive check, it may, under exceptional cases, request for verification
visits to Palestine.
(i) Prior to the conduct of a verification visit pursuant to the provisions
herein, the Customs Authority of Indonesia shall notify the Competent
Governmental Authority with an aim to mutually agree on the conditions
and means of the verification visit.
(ii) The verification visit shall be conducted not later than sixty (60)
calendar days after receipt of the notification pursuant to sub-paragraph
(a) (i).
(b) The verification process, including the retroactive check and verification
visit, shall be carried out and its results communicated to the Customs
Authority of Indonesia and/or the Competent Governmental Authority within
a maximum of one hundred and eighty (180) calendar days. While awaiting
the results of the verification visit, Article 17 (c) on the suspension of tarifs
elimination treatment shall be applied.
(c) The tarifs elimination treatment may be denied when Palestine fails to
respond to the request to the satisfaction of the Customs Authority of
Indonesia in the course of a retroactive check or verification process, as the
case may be, within the time frame for verification under Article 17, Article
18 paragraphs (a) and (b).
CONSIGNMENT DOCUMENT
For the purpose of implementing Rule 8 (Direct Consignment) of Annex II
(Rules of Origin) where transportation is efected through the territory of any
non-Parties, the following shall be provided to the Customs Authority of Indonesia:
a) a through Bill of Lading issued in Palestine; or
b) a certificate or any other information given by the customs authority of such
ARTICLE 20:
non-Parties or other relevant entities, which evidences that the good has not
undergone operations other than unloading, reloading and any other
operation to preserve it in good condition in those non-Parties.
DISPUTE SETTLEMENT AND ACTIONS AGAINST FRAUDULENT ACTS
a) When it is suspected that fraudulent acts in connection with the Certificate of
Origin have been committed, the Competent Governmental Authority
In the case of a dispute concerning origin determination, classification of
b) Each Party shall be responsible for providing legal sanctions for fraudulent
acts related to the Certificate of Origin.
Article 21:
products or other matters, the Competent Governmental Authority concerned in
both the importing and the exporting party shall consult each other with a view
to resolve the dispute, and the result shall be reported to the other Party for information.
